comments.commentBody: I thought how much I would like my granddaughters to read this.  Also, how lucky I was to have had parents who shared some of the same wisdom.  Justice Gingsberg is bright spot in a troubling political climate.
Lovely to read about her strong and supportive marriage. It is amazing how much we can learn and benefit from a kind, robust cheerleader at home.
Thank you Justice Ginsburg for your service, and blazing trails that today people of my age take for granted are available to all on merit.

What inspiring and wise words from Ruth Bader Ginsburg. I am the age of her children and I, too, had a mother who was a professional at a time when most of my friends' mothers did not work. I did not appreciate that gift as much then as I do now. May we all give gifts to younger generations.

There are many ways in which I find Ruth Bader Ginsburg an awesome lady.  Reading this essay, I find her awesome in her recognition of how much her in-laws had to offer her, how much of a resource they were.

Thank you Justice Ginsburg for your insightful observations of a life fulfilled. The key thing I picked up in your piece was the use of the word "collegiality". A most apropos word, for we of late have become so strident in out beliefs we seem to have abandoned that word, as well as the words compromise, empathy and the ability to walk in another person's shoes.

I wish you continued good health and judgement on the Court and off.

DD
Manhattan

Dear Just Sayn', I too had to transfer law schools to earn my JD in 1972. My husband changed jobs from DC to San Francisco. I didn't have a RBG to help though. It took my husband to plead to Stanford's law dean to use the principle of 'comity' to accommodate my need for a third law school year in exchange for his federal appointment. I already had 3 children and no firm would hire me in 1972 citing the fear that I would move again when my husband's employment advanced. Only one firm showed interest, but only for my supposed talents as an 'escort' for potential clients. Can you imagine? Does this still happen?
What a lovely and inspiring story. Thank you for sharing it.

Just Sayin' --

"I have carried your grace with me everywhere and paid forward what you did for me."

What a lovely testimonial to RBG from one who is evidently still paying it forward.

I am a female lawyer, class of 1974. In the early 1970s I found it necessary to transfer from my first-year law school in one city to a law school in another city - a difficult situation for the very few female law students at that time. Most transfers, I heard, were for (male) law students in the military. I went to hear a presentation by the then pioneer women's rights lawyer - Ruth Bader Ginsburg. After her inspiring presentation, I went up to thank her and mentioned my situation, asking for advice. This lovely, loving woman offered to write a letter for me to the law school I wanted to transfer to. She did, and I was admitted. Thanks to "my hero," I had a 40-year legal career followed by 6 years in "retirement" of teaching lawyers in and from all over the world. I hope she reads this comment and my thanks to her. I have loved her for all these years from afar and have told this story in tribute to her hundreds of times in the U.S. and abroad. Thank you, Ruth Bader Ginsburg, for my happy and successful life. I have carried your grace with me everywhere and paid forward what you did for me.
Have you ever thought of the ableism in that term? And the difference between "can't hear" and "won't hear?"

“...it helps sometimes to be a little deaf.”

Thank you, Justice Ginsburg. This advice has come just at the right time; I will diligently put it into practice for the next five weeks. And then again, should all go well, over the next eight years, the better to be productive and compassionate when those who are uncomfortable with a woman President obstruct.

And thank you to your mother, your teachers, your mentors. They gave you strong shoulders which have taken a lot of weight; your many years of service have lifted us all, women and men, girls and boys. Thank you, thank you, thank you.

Justice Ginsburg, thank you for your wisdom and your service. It's truly lamentable that Federal judges are now subject to Congressional political litmus tests that have nothing to  do with their knowledge of the law, their scholarship, their accomplishments or with their probity. I have no doubt that in today's environment you would not be considered for a Federal judgeship, and that is sad indeed.

Establishment supporting and perpetuating establishment.
This is what has begotten Trump.

If you think that the Democrats don't want to control you too, you haven't been paying attention. Both parties devote a lot of effort to keep non-Washington insiders out of the game, although the Republicans failed this time around.

I'm curious why, if you don"t agree with the content of my comments, you didn't put together a rebuttal?

RBG's decision in favor of the oligarch's right to control the political process via legalized bribery is part of a pattern that's been evident for a few centuries.

Believe me, if one of the conservative justices had inexplicably decided against Citizens United's case, one of the "liberal" justices would have stepped forward with an "inexplicable" vote FOR Citizens United. The primacy of big money in politics must be held sacrosanct, and no one will be appointed to the SCOTUS who doesn't have a long track record congruent with that dictum.

Congress members do the same thing. When legislation favoring the ruling case is sure to pass, some will be free to vote on the side of the people, so that come election time, they can point to one or two populist votes and declare, "I am a candidate of the people".

That's why the only explanation for the unanimous vote to vacate the corruption conviction had to be that the justices wanted to thoroughly discourage further convictions of the wealthy for wielding their power over politicians.

"Despite our strong disagreements on cardinal issues — think, for example, of controls on political campaign spending, affirmative action, access to abortion — we genuinely respect one another, even enjoy one another’s company."

There was one "cardinal issue" in which they all "enjoyed one another's company", - the unanimous decision to vacate the conviction of a corrupt Republican governor. The unanimity was unusual in a case which boiled down to the right of the country's oligarchs to buy politicians with "gifts".

Usually, the so-called "liberal", Democratic-appointed judges will trust that the conservative (reactionary, really) majority will win the day, so that they may maintain their liberal facade and support the minority position, but apparently the "liberal" judges wanted to send a message to prosecutors across the country: the wealthy are free to bribe politicians for the purpose of controlling the political process.

Even Justice Roberts conceded that the governor's case was a “tawdry tale...of Ferraris, Rolexes and ball gowns,” but the court made it clear that unless the parties involved are sufficiently clueless to leave evidence of quid pro quo, don't bother prosecuting.

There is often talk of "litmus tests" during SCOTUS confirmations, always denied, but there is surely one area which is subject to such vetting: the nominee may be conservative or liberal on social issues, but the nominee must demonstrate obsequiousness to the ruling class.

That would be a really interesting conjecture/article - What would politician/elected person RBG be like? How would the politics of getting elected every 2, 4 or 6 years treat or effect her and her constituents and colleagues?
Would that members of other branches of our government exhibit the wisdom, maturity, and perspective of Justice Ginsburg.

Your presence is deeply felt here, Ms. Ginsberg, and very much appreciated. I hear my father's voice in your balanced reasoning, directness, compassion and humour. He was a union representative for the AFL-CIO in Buffalo many years ago, and occasionally wrote pieces for the News there, with that same kind of native intelligence, penned by someone who doesn't miss a trick and has heart, ears, and eyes wide open. You are a truly great American, as he was! Cent'anni! (or due cent'anni, in your case!)
God Bless America, and Ruth Bader Ginsberg. We are better because of you.
Too bad the collegiality and respect doesn't filter down to the Wisconsin Supreme Court.

The presumed respect the justices at the Supreme Court have for one another must be couched in the comfort of their lifetime appointments; not a leap to realize the lack of respect among members of Congress is couched in their obvious insecurity.

A generous thoughtful piece. Many thanks for sharing your personal history and reminding all of us of the changes that have taken place and the challenges we continue to face. It's a pleasure to read of partnership and collegiality and to reflect on the rewards of focus, discipline and hard work. Your words and example offer a clear and positive path. I'm hoping we'll continue to have both for years to come. Many thanks.
RBG is my hero.

This wise woman is a national treasure.

In the continuing slow rolling train wreck that our politics has become, we (those of all parties and persuasions) when confronted with intractable issues and intransigent foes would do well to ask 'What would Ruth do?"

Such joy in this heart-felt and heart-warming essay. The photo of RGB at her confirmation hearing captures pure delight as she shares the moment with her Marty. Her life and her loves are a continuing inspiration.
I know it's a cliché, but she is an inspiration to all.

I hope it in no way undermines her intellect, her accomplishments and her compassion if I say I think she is adorable as well as brilliant.   What a thoughtful loving person.  I very much admire her husband Martin D Ginsburg who is a wonderful role model to the rest of us men. Just as wives have for millenniums provided emotional support for their husbands to succeed, women need that same care and support from their husbands.  L'Shonah Tovah to Ruth Bader Ginsburg and her family.

What a wonderful piece of writing by a very admirable woman. As to her observation of the persistent lag of women as equal members of our constitutional government, the time might be right to finally ratify the Equal Rights Amendment. Affirmation in the Constitution of women's equality is a couple of centuries overdue - and it matters a great deal.
Thank you, Justice Ginsberg, for advancing women's rights throughout your long and brilliant career. You are truly one of the great Americans of my lifetime.
Unfortunately for him, it was a full year after the invasion. Nice try, though.

Excellent. You said it all.

Why do they (Trump and Hannity) get along? Because they're both pathological liars, wrapped up in the flag, willing to say anything (as often as it takes) to dupe those predisposed to having their ears tickled. Peas in a pod.

Neil Cavuto and Donald Trump spoke two months before the war in Iraq. But nothing is mentioned about how Donald Trump went onto say that he felt like that there were issues at home that were more important than the war in Iraq. Granted he's not rioting and having a protest march but you can certainly see where he is not in favor of it.
